list_definition.definition: to move slowly along the ground
(of people) to move on hands and knees or with the front of the body on the ground

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The baby can’t walk yet, but she crawls everywhere.
The traffic was crawling along at ten kilometres per hour.

list_definition.definition: to be covered with crawling things

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: His hair was crawling with lice.

list_definition.definition: a very slow movement or speed

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: We drove along at a crawl.

list_definition.definition: a style of swimming in which the arms make alternate overarm movements

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: She’s better at the crawl than she is at the breaststroke.

list_ex_of_english: There are armed men crawling all over the building you are in.
She was crawling around in circles.
One finds buses ahead of schedule crawling along our main roads.
I do not mind spending time crawling all over this issue.
A fully equipped and fitted out diner was much heavier than a mobile home, and when it was towed on its own wheels it moved at a crawling pace.
The females readily crawled onto the host, and typically oviposited within a few seconds.
Reaching, sitting, crawling, grasping, walking, and throwing are just a few of the plethora of skills babies master in their first few years of life.
We understand kerb crawling to be driving down roads slowly while looking for ladies to solicit.
